Published in Engineered Septic, Septic

Septic tank maintenance and care

By byronwadeMarch 22, 2023 at 6:10 AM

Taking care of your septic tank is an important task that should not be overlooked. A septic tank is a self-contained underground chamber that is designed to hold and treat sewage. It is a crucial component of any home or business that is not connected to a municipal sewer system. Unfortunately, many people are unaware of the proper maintenance and care required for their septic tank, which can lead to costly repairs and replacements. In this blog post, we will discuss the importance of regular septic tank maintenance and provide tips on how to properly care for your septic tank.

Understanding How a Septic Tank Works

First and foremost, it is important to understand that a septic tank operates through a process of natural bacterial digestion. This means that there are certain things that should not be disposed of in your septic tank, such as harsh chemicals, grease, and non-biodegradable materials. These materials can disrupt the natural bacterial digestion process and cause blockages or backups. To ensure the proper functioning of your septic tank, it is important to only flush biodegradable materials and avoid disposing of non-biodegradable materials.

Regular Septic Tank Pumping

Another important aspect of septic tank maintenance is regular pumping. Septic tanks should be pumped every 3-5 years, depending on the size of the tank and the number of people using it. This process involves removing the sludge and scum that has accumulated in the tank over time. Failure to pump your septic tank regularly can lead to the tank overflowing, which can cause serious damage to your property and the environment.

To help you understand more about septic tank pumping and how often you should do it, you can check out this article from HomeAdvisor that goes into more detail about the process and how often it should be done.

Professional Septic Tank Inspection

In addition to regular pumping, it is also important to have your septic tank inspected by a professional at least once a year. A professional inspection can detect any potential problems early on, before they become serious issues. They can also provide you with an accurate assessment of the condition of your septic tank and advise you on any necessary repairs or replacements. If you’re looking for a professional septic tank inspector, you can check out the National Onsite Wastewater Recycling Association (NOWRA) website to find a certified inspector near you.

Landscaping around the Septic Tank

Lastly, it is important to be mindful of the landscaping around your septic tank. Trees and shrubs should not be planted too close to the tank as their roots can damage the tank and pipes. Additionally, heavy vehicles and equipment should not be driven over the tank as this can cause damage. If you’re unsure about what types of plants are safe to plant near your septic tank, you can check out this article from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) that provides guidance on landscaping around septic systems.

Conclusion

In conclusion, regular maintenance and proper care are crucial for the proper functioning and longevity of your septic tank. By following the tips outlined in this blog post, you can ensure that your septic tank continues to operate effectively for years to come. Remember to avoid disposing of non-biodegradable materials in your septic tank.
